title: Pentagon Advances Plan to Shift $3.6 Billion in Military Funds to Border Wall
summary: Money would be diverted from military-construction projects that Congress has approved. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration is moving ahead with plans to divert $3.6 billion from military-construction projects to build or fortify portions of a wall along the U.S.-Mexico border.

title: U.S. Sanctions Iran's Space Agency After Failed Launch
summary: State Department said technologies used to launch rockets are virtually identical to those used to test ballistic missiles. WASHINGTON-The State Department imposed sanctions against Iran's space program on Tuesday following a failed attempt to launch a rocket last week, which the U.S. suspects was an effort to advance its ballistic missile program.

title: United Auto Workers to Target GM First in Labor Negotiations
summary: Union aims to reach new deal with the Detroit auto maker that can be used to set the pattern for talks with Ford, Fiat Chrysler. The United Auto Workers union said Tuesday it would target General Motors Co. first in negotiating a new labor contract, aiming for a deal that can be used to guide talks with the other two Detroit car companies.

title: U.S. Factory Activity Shrinks for First Time in 3 Years
summary: Sagging manufacturing in August, burdened by trade tensions, sends markets lower. The U.S. manufacturing sector shrank for the first time in three years last month, providing the latest sign that a global manufacturing pullback is weighing on the American economy amid rising trade tensions between Washington and Beijing.

title: British Lawmakers Upset Johnson's Brexit Plan
summary: Opposition and rebel lawmakers move to force prime minister to ask the EU for a further extension, prompting him to call for snap election. LONDON-U.K. lawmakers delivered a blow to Prime Minister Boris Johnson's Brexit strategy with a vote aimed at delaying the country's exit from the European Union, prompting the British leader to call for a general election.

title: Dollar Index Climbs to Two-Year High
summary: China's yuan trades at fresh 11-year low, nearing 7.2 to the dollar. The dollar ticked higher Tuesday, touching its highest level in more than two years as the gloomy outlook for global growth, rising U.S.-China trade tensions and political turmoil in Europe weighed on major currencies world-wide.

title: North Carolina's GOP-Drawn Map Is Struck Down
summary: Panel of judges rules that present legislative districts violate free-elections clause in state's Constitution. A panel of state-court judges struck down North Carolina's legislative districts Tuesday, ruling that Republicans improperly gerrymandered state voting lines to provide an enduring political majority for the GOP.

title: Trump Warns China Not to Stall Talks
summary: President says its economy will suffer unless Beijing strikes trade deal before 2020 election. WASHINGTON-President Trump said he would redouble his pressure on China if he wins a second term, warning Beijing not to stall trade negotiations until after the 2020 U.S. election and vowing to stick with his go-it-alone approach to the discussions.

title: Trump's Manufacturing SOS
summary: Tariffs and trade uncertainty punish U.S. goods makers.. Mayday, mayday. The U.S. manufacturing boom is showing signs of distress. Business investment has plunged amid growing trade uncertainty, and another warning came Tuesday in the Institute for Supply Management survey that showed manufacturing contracted last month for the first time since 2016.

title: More Trouble at the UAW
summary: A federal corruption probe of the union appears to be expanding.. Labor Day must have been grim this year at the headquarters of the United Auto Workers. Federal agents last week raided the homes of the union's president, Gary Jones, and a former president. They haven't been criminally charged, but it's an escalation of a probe that has already won guilty pleas.

title: Here's What's Sure to Happen in 2020
summary: Whoever Trump faces, voter turnout and the economy will be decisive.. Autumn is approaching, and the Iowa caucuses convene five months from Tuesday. It's time to start thinking about the forces that will shape the 2020 general election.

title: A Scientific Roundup
summary: The EPA intervenes against California's rogue cancer regulation.. Perhaps you've read that science should rule when determining environmental standards. So why aren't progressives cheering an Environmental Protection Agency order declaring that the chemical glyphosate doesn't cause cancer?

title: How Bad Can a Trade War Get?
summary: The Trump China policy has fixed no problem, but the recovery can survive it.. For the 2020 election, the big question is: Can the decoupling of the U.S. economy from China take place without tanking the U.S. economy? It's not impossible. After all, other low-wage countries are eager to take over China's role and keep the products flowing (no, those jobs won't be coming to the U.S.). Apple may have a big adjustment to make but also has big profit margins to absorb the cost. China still wants American technology. Boeing jetliners won't be easily replaced. If China buys Brazilian soybeans, Brazil's existing customers will have to buy soybeans elsewhere. For these reasons, I suspect a decoupling in U.S.-China trade relations would be less damaging, say, than any that might follow from Mr. Trump's occasional threats to impose heavy tariffs on Japan and Europe to blow up the supply chains of an integrated world-wide auto industry.

title: 'Without the Banya We Would Perish' Review: Sweat Like a Russian
summary: "Either socialism will defeat the louse," Lenin famously declared, "or the louse will defeat socialism." The louse won.. The Russian communal bathhouse, or banya, where people are steamed at extreme heat, beat each other with birch branches, and then jump into cold water or snow, has struck many observers as a foretaste of hell. Svidrigailov, the debauched cynic of Dostoevsky's "Crime and Punishment," suggests that the other world, far from being vast and imposing, as Dante and Milton imagined, resembles "a little room, like a banya in the country, grimy and sooty, with spiders in every corner." When in 1919 the Princess Sofia Volkonskaya, having been deprived of her property, was forced to visit an urban banya, she saw filth, soot, deformity and-as she wrote in a later memoir-"itching scabes . . . necks and shoulders powdered with the pink patches of syphilitic roseolas . . . lice of many months accumulation. . . . If hell exists, it surely resembles that bathing room."

title: Tyson Cuts Full-Year Profit Forecast
summary: Shares of the meatpacking company fell 6.2% to $87.50 in after-hours trading. Tyson Foods Inc. lowered its earnings forecast for the current period, citing "short-term challenges" that have weighed on its bottom line, including volatile commodity prices and food-safety initiatives.

title: End the Media's Campaign Privilege
summary: As journalism blurs into partisan politics, the rules governing the latter are becoming unjustifiable.. The Trump era has seen an erosion of the distinction between journalism and partisan politics, with much of the mainstream media in open opposition to the president. "Balance has been on vacation since Mr. Trump stepped onto his golden Trump Tower escalator . . . to announce his candidacy," New York Times columnist Jim Rutenberg wrote in August 2016.

title: Cutting Medical Costs Can Be a Bargain
summary: Don't underestimate inexpensive, low-tech methods of keeping people healthy.. Much of the medical progress in the past half-century has involved expensive, high-tech diagnostic tests and therapies. But it would be a mistake to gainsay the value of inexpensive, low-tech innovations.

title: Dave Chappelle Is Stuck in the '80s
summary: He made a career pushing the envelope, but his material-including the N-word-is no longer edgy.. I had three major takeaways from comic Dave Chappelle's most recent Netflix special. The first was that his comedy has lost something. The flourishes are still there but less frequent. The observations are still amusing but less reliably insightful. Mr. Chappelle has made a career out of pushing the envelope, but his Michael Jackson pedophile bits aren't edgy. They're just icky.

title: Economics Is Dismal, but Is It Science?
summary: A discipline that loves to challenge common sense makes me suspicious of its confident predictions.. Given the scuttlebutt about a possible recession, over the next few weeks we are likely to hear from a good many economists. With the trained verbosity of experts and the unshakable confidence that seems to be part of their training, they will tell us not to worry, or to worry, or that it is too early to know whether or not to worry. None of this is likely to give much comfort.

title: China Finds It Can Live Without the U.S.
summary: Hawks in Washington speak of 'decoupling.' Xi Jinping is already busy doing that-his way.. A China hand and former Treasury Department colleague told me before the 2016 election that officials in Beijing preferred Donald Trump to Hillary Clinton because they thought Mr. Trump would be an easier negotiator.

title: FedEx Comes Under Further Scrutiny in China
summary: Investigation launched into delivery company for allegedly shipping a parcel of knives to Hong Kong. SHANGHAI- FedEx Corp. faces another investigation in China, this time suspected of illegally shipping a parcel containing knives to Hong Kong, state media said.

title: What an 'Adversity Score' Misses
summary: Students discuss the role hardship should play in college admissions decisions.. Editor's note: This Future View is about the College Board's "adversity scores." For next week, we'll ask: To what do you attribute the sharp rise in depression, anxiety and suicidal thinking reported by college students over the last decade? Students should click here to submit opinions of fewer than 250 words before Sept. 10. The best responses will be published that night.

title: Amazon CTO Details Company's Path to the Cloud Business
summary: Werner Vogels spells out how early problems with IT led to Amazon Web Services. Amazon.com Inc.'s dominance in cloud computing is the result of early struggles with its information-technology system as the e-commerce giant sought to expand beyond online book sales, a top executive said.

title: AT&T Names Media Boss as CEO Heir Apparent
summary: WarnerMedia chief will serve as No. 2 for CEO Randall Stephenson after winning succession race. AT&T Inc. promoted longtime executive John Stankey to a newly created No. 2 role, setting up the WarnerMedia boss as the likely successor to Chief Executive Randall Stephenson.

title: Bankrupt Loot Crate Gets Creditor Bid of More Than $30 Million
summary: Monthly subscription service whose shareholders include actor Robert Downey Jr. has baseline offer for potential auction. Loot Crate Inc., the "geek and gamer" subscription business backed by actor Robert Downey Jr.'s venture-capital firm, plans to sell itself for more than $30 million to a creditor that will use the debt it is owed as currency.

title: Gun-Policy Talks Await Signal From Trump
summary: President has yet to throw his weight behind any specific proposals. WASHINGTON-After a congressional recess marked by multiple high-profile mass shootings, lawmakers are set to return to Capitol Hill amid widespread uncertainty about whether they and President Trump can agree on gun legislation.

title: New Software Tool Helps Arrow Electronics CFO Cut Costs
summary: The electronics distributor, which sells to small and medium-size industrial businesses, plans to cut $130 million in costs by year-end. The finance chief of Arrow Electronics Inc. is turning to software to help eke out $130 million in annual cost savings across the electronics distributor's operations, an effort that could be widened should the company's outlook worsen as a consequence of the trade tensions between the U.S. and China.

title: 'Father Is Surgeon,' '1 Mil Pledge': The Role of Money in USC Admissions
summary: Emails in college admissions cheating scandal show the role donations played in decisions to accept students. BOSTON-Emails among athletics, admissions and fundraising officials at the University of Southern California show the school explicitly weighed how much money applicants' families could donate when determining whether to admit students.

title: New York City Declares Measles Outbreak Over
summary: Emergency order, which mandated vaccines in some areas of Brooklyn, is lifted. New York City's measles outbreak is over, health officials said Tuesday, as a public-health emergency order was lifted.

title: Deere Sells 30-Year Corporate Bonds at Record Low Yields
summary: Treasury yields dropped sharply on weak manufacturing data. Deere & Co. sold 30-year bonds at a record low yield for U.S. corporate debt of that maturity on Tuesday, seizing on tumbling U.S. Treasury yields to lock in favorable interest rates.

title: New York Fed Lays Out Projections for Future of Fed Holdings
summary: Central bank's holdings of assets and bonds could again increase sometime between later this year and 2025. The Federal Reserve's balance sheet, which has recently stopped shrinking, may once again start growing later this year, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said Tuesday.

title: Fed's Rosengren: Economy Doing Fine Despite Risks to Outlook
summary: Boston Fed leader sees no need for rate cuts now, pending further signs of risk. Boston Fed leader Eric Rosengren said Tuesday the U.S. economy still seems in a good enough place to avoid the need for rate cuts, in comments that shrugged off bond-market pricing levels that suggest a downturn is looming.

title: U.S. Stocks Fall Amid Trade Tensions, Weak Data
summary: Dow falls 285 points as investors parse fresh economic data. Stocks and government-bond yields slumped Tuesday as a drop in manufacturing activity intensified worries about the global economy and the impact of trade tensions between the U.S. and China.

title: New York City Opens Office to Combat Hate-Crimes Increase
summary: Former executive of Anti-Defamation League named as the director of the new office. A former executive of the Anti-Defamation League was named the director of a new office that will work to stem the surge in hate crimes in New York City, including two over Labor Day weekend at Rockaway Beach, city officials said Tuesday.

title: Bank Stocks Fall on Global Growth Worries
summary: The sector slumped Tuesday amid concerns over the outlook for the global economy. Bank stocks came under pressure Tuesday as weak manufacturing data and a drop in bond yields renewed fears over a slowdown in U.S. economic growth.

title: Companies Use Cyber Ranges to Practice Security Skills
summary: Mastercard built a range to experiment with offensive and defensive measures. Companies and universities around the country are building cybersecurity training centers that simulate real-world networks and breaches to train staff and test theories about how to guard against and respond to attacks.

title: 'Norman F-ing Rockwell!' by Lana Del Rey Review: The Magic and Mystery of Life
summary: Touching simplicity reigns on the star's latest album, which moves through humor, anger, heartbreak and, occasionally, moments of peace..

title: Bangladesh Cuts Mobile Access to Rohingya Refugees
summary: Government says move will curb criminal networks, but activists say it will further isolate the troubled community. Bangladesh says it will end Rohingya refugees' access to mobile-phone services and their primary means of connecting to the internet, a significant blow to a major refugee population that relies on mobile networks to communicate with relatives and monitor news from their homeland of Myanmar.

title: 'Gorham Silver: Designing Brilliance 1850-1970' Review: All That Glitters
summary: An exhibition of more than 600 silver and mixed-metal wares reveals the artistry and innovation of the Rhode Island firm..

title: Pope Orders Officials to Shrink Budget Deficit
summary: Pope Francis struggles with mission to fix finances at Holy See. VATICAN CITY-Pope Francis ordered Vatican officials to close a widening budget deficit at the Holy See and stop poorly managed spending and investments from undermining the operations of the Catholic Church's global headquarters.

title: Pence Defends Stay at Trump Property in Ireland
summary: Vice president says the site could accommodate his entourage and security staff; critics say it benefits Trump's company. DUBLIN-Vice President Mike Pence defended his two-night stay at President Trump's golf resort on an official visit to Ireland, as some question whether he is using public dollars to benefit the president.

title: Trade Impasse Sends Oil Prices Lower
summary: Hurricane Dorian's expected path should keep it from disrupting oil production in the Gulf of Mexico. Oil prices dropped Tuesday as concerns mounted over the China-U.S. trade impasse and as Hurricane Dorian rumbled along a path that should keep it from disrupting production in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: ER Visits Precede First-Time Entry Into New York Homeless Shelters, Study Shows
summary: Researchers found that 39.3% of first-time adult shelter users visited the emergency department for treatment or were hospitalized in the year before the shelter entry. New York City physicians have long observed a higher-than-average use of the emergency department by the homeless. What was less understood is how visits to the emergency room are connected to first-time shelter use.

title: Celebrity-Backed Matcha Chain Tries Putting Its Cool Into Cans
summary: Cha Cha Matcha, the green tea shop with fashion buzz, is betting on millennial love of canned drinks. In 2016, two NYU graduates, Conrad Sandelman, 26, and Matthew Morton, 27, the son of Hard Rock Café co-founder Peter Morton, opened a storefront in Manhattan hawking colorful drinks made with matcha, the Japanese powdered green tea. They called it Cha Cha Matcha (tagline: "I love you so matcha"). Caffeinated customers posed for selfies against the stores' millennial-pink and green walls and with the company's pastel products. The brand forged partnerships with its fans in the fashion industry, collaborating with major brands on merchandise, including Kith x Versace and buzzy designer Virgil Abloh. Models like Kendall Jenner and Gigi Hadid have been photographed with the green beverage, while the New York Post described it in 2016 as the "must-have beverage of Victoria's Secret models."

title: Dorian Is Exposing an Insurance Gap in the Bahamas
summary: Much of the insurance in place covers the islands' hospitality industry, not individual residences. The vast majority of damage caused by Hurricane Dorian to the Bahamas and other Caribbean countries is unlikely to be covered by insurance, which could slow recovery in the region.

title: Plan to Close Rikers Island Jail Complex Gets Key Approval
summary: Local residents have expressed concerns, saying construction, traffic and tall buildings will harm their communities. New York City's planning commission voted Tuesday to allow a plan to build four new jails to move forward, clearing a hurdle to shuttering the jail complex on Rikers Island.

title: Goldman's Coder-in-Chief Ditches Wall Street for California Sunshine
summary: Martin Chavez typified the new breed of engineers ruling the financial industry, overseeing the firm's push to digitize. Martin Chavez began planning his escape from Wall Street in January.

title: Italy's 5 Star Approves Coalition Government With Ex-Foes
summary: The move heads off the risk of new elections and prolonged political instability. ROME-Members of Italy's antiestablishment 5 Star Movement voted to form a coalition government with its former center-left Democratic Party foes, clearing the last major hurdle to new leadership.

title: Students Using Phones Too Much in Class? Blame Parents.
summary: Schools are instituting phone bans to cut down on classroom distractions; 'My mother texts me all the time'. Cellphone usage in class is getting so out of control that some schools are locking up students' phones during the day. Here's a notification for you parents: You're partly to blame.

title: Why This Fall Is the Ideal Time to Visit Chicago
summary: Happy hour at a Frank Lloyd Wright house-and about 100 other reasons why architecture fans should plan a trip to Chicago before the end of the year. THE WINDY CITY has long been catnip for architects and design buffs, and it's even more so this fall. The third Chicago Architecture Biennial kicks off Sept. 19 and runs through early January, unfurling more than 100 tours, events and exhibits, including new work from artist Theaster Gates. chicagoarchitecturebiennial.org

title: Psychedelic Drugs Draw Some Investor Attention-and Much Skepticism
summary: A few entrepreneurs and investors see opportunity for novel mental-health treatments, but traditional health-care investors say it is too early. Psychedelic substances are gaining legitimacy as a treatment for mental illnesses, prompting a handful of entrepreneurs and venture-capital investors to look for business opportunities in the nascent sector.

title: Trump Administration Mulls Cutting Refugee Cap, Keeping Iraqi Program
summary: More than two dozen retired generals and admirals appeal to White House to continue broad allowance for all refugee applicants. The Trump administration is weighing continuing a special refugee program for some Iraqis while further reducing the cap on other refugees allowed into the U.S., according to people familiar with internal deliberations.

title: Urbanists Sometimes Forget Urban Residents
summary: My mother-in-law lived in Manhattan for over 100 of her 105 years, walking to a bus stop a few times a week. When she couldn't do that anymore, she took a cab to her medical appointments and social outings. Her independence depended on the availability of automobiles.. I was quite alarmed by Christopher F. Rufo's "'New Left Urbanists' Want to Remake Your City" (op-ed, Aug. 23). Do the people who think up these "improvements" consider or even care about the negative impact on the residents? I strongly agree that residents and developers need to be included in discussions of these long-ranging effects on housing, development and transportation.

title: Mileage Deal Is a Step in the Right Direction
summary: At the very least, the deal between the states, Ford, Honda, Volkswagen and BMW is a step in the right direction to stabilize market signals, preserving our long-term investments in innovative technologies and protecting jobs.. Regarding your editorial "The Great California Mileage Con" (Aug. 12): As a supplier, our sector of the automotive industry employs two-and-a-half times as many people as the auto makers themselves. Recent research shows that rolling back the current standards will have a chilling impact on auto-industry investments, which could threaten between 89,000 and 202,000 of tomorrow's clean-vehicle technology jobs. At the very least, the deal between the states that have adopted California's emissions standards and Ford, Honda, Volkswagen and BMW is a step in the right direction to stabilize market signals, preserving our long-term investments in innovative technologies and protecting jobs.

title: The Amazon Site: Hey, It's A Real Jungle Out There
summary: "Amazon Has Ceded Control of Its Site" sheds light on a little-discussed area of trade policy: the competitive advantage overseas firms enjoy over American companies with regard to regulatory compliance.. "Amazon Has Ceded Control of Its Site" (Exchange, Aug. 24) sheds light on a little-discussed area of trade policy: the competitive advantage overseas firms enjoy over American companies with regard to regulatory compliance. Aside from the safety, patent and copyright implications of myriad knockoff products sold online, there is a substantial price advantage for companies that ignore U.S. consumer protections, UL safety-testing requirements and other hurdles that American companies must overcome. This is on top of the environmental, worker-protection and other standards required of American companies, which developing countries conveniently ignore.

title: Price Rises Above Inflation Already Standard for Drugs
summary: In the past three years, more than half of all sales growth for the top 45-selling drugs was due to price increases.. In your editorial "The Right's Left Turn on Drug Prices" (Aug. 19), you criticize a new U.S. Senate Finance Committee proposal to cap Medicare drug-price increases at the rate of inflation. You predict that the measure will "cause companies to launch drugs at higher prices"-a claim that is plausible only if we assume that industry executives aren't currently setting the profit-maximizing price. That seems unlikely.

title: Is China's 'Social Credit' Heading to Hong Kong?
summary: One can't imagine a more toxic poison to Hong Kong's free-market culture than the imposition of China's "social credit.". Having read F.H. Buckley's "'Social Credit' May Come to America" (op-ed, Aug. 29) on "social credit" in China, I now better understand why the Hong Kong protesters so desperately oppose China getting a stronger foothold in the territory. I visited Hong Kong a few years ago and saw its incredibly diverse and vibrant arts, culture and free-market economy and I, too, would fight. One can't imagine a more toxic poison to that environment than the imposition of "social credit." The only question I have is why haven't the international companies doing business in Hong Kong come to the same conclusion.

title: Japan Should Consider the Larger Picture With Korea
summary: As for South Korea and Japan, any alliance between the two is on shaky ground because of the historic enmity between them.. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo very well might have cause to be concerned about the security implications of South Korea's decision to withdraw from its intelligence-sharing agreement with Japan, but President Trump himself sets a precedent for unilateral withdrawal from agreements that turn out not to suit one's national interests ("Tensions in Asia Weaken Alliance," Page One, Aug. 23). As for South Korea and Japan, any alliance between the two is on shaky ground because of the historic enmity between them. Under the circumstances, it would behoove Japan to be very circumspect in its dealings with South Korea instead of acting in its old, imperious manner.

title: Huawei Accuses the U.S. of Cyberattacks and Staff Threats
summary: Chinese tech giant describes campaign by U.S. officials to disrupt its business; it doesn't provide evidence to back up allegations. HONG KONG-China's Huawei Technologies Co. accused the U.S. of "using every tool at its disposal" to disrupt its business, including launching cyberattacks on its networks and instructing law enforcement to "menace" its employees.

title: Transcript: Reporters Hear From Richmond Fed President Tom Barkin
summary: Resume Subscription. Richmond Fed President Tom Barkin met with reporters after a speech Wednesday, Aug. 28, in White Sulphur Springs, W.Va. He discussed his outlook for the economy and interest rates in an environment of heightened policy uncertainty. Here is a partial transcript of the interview, lightly edited for clarity and length.

title: Another Recession Sign to Ignore at Your Peril
summary: A worrying signal from the ISM Manufacturing Survey follows an inversion of the yield curve, and it no longer makes sense to keep explaining such signs away. Signs of a possible recession keep stacking up. At some point it no longer makes sense to keep explaining them away.

title: Overseas Investors Unload U.S. Real Estate
summary: In the second quarter, foreign investors pulled more money out of the U.S. commercial real-estate market than they put in. A strong appetite among foreign investors for office buildings, apartments, malls and other real estate has in part fueled the long-running bull market in U.S. commercial property.

title: Team USA's Huge Sigh of Relief
summary: Turkey misses four free throws in the last 10 seconds, and the Americans escape with a win. It won't be the last time they're tested in the FIBA World Cup.. The best player in their country isn't playing because he's been labeled an enemy of the state by its president. Their leading scorer comes off the bench in the NBA. Their starting point guard is a naturalized citizen born and raised in Florida. They are the 17th best team in the world-and they almost beat Team USA.

title: Coco Gauff Is the Future. But It Still Looks Thin on the Men's Side.
summary: It's been 16 years since Andy Roddick won the U.S. Open. The U.S. men's Grand Slam drought is likely to continue with no stars on the horizon.. Every year American men play at all four Grand Slam singles events, and every year American men lose. Andy Roddick was the last U.S. man to win a major title, 16 years ago in 2003. And everyone agrees that this drought will likely continue, with no stars on the horizon.

title: Democratic Candidates Ramp Up for Renewed Campaign Push
summary: With Iowa caucuses five months away, the race is still wide open. CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa-Democratic presidential candidates are ramping up for a post-Labor Day push to win the party's nomination for the White House, with Iowa caucuses now just five months away and the race still wide open.

title: A Cincinnati Neighborhood With a Presidential Past
summary: Mt. Adams is one of the oldest-and priciest-communities in the southwestern Ohio city. Of Cincinnati's 52 neighborhoods, Mt. Adams, on a hill east of downtown, is one of the southwestern Ohio city's most historic communities. Its first road dates back to 1793, and its name pays homage to President John Quincy Adams, who came to town in 1843 to dedicate the Cincinnati Observatory. The area has a 19th-century European mountain village vibe, with 680 of its roughly 1,000 houses built before 1939 on narrow streets abutting the landmark Eden Park. Today, Mt. Adams commands some of the priciest residential real estate in Cincinnati proper. The approximately 1,500-person neighborhood with a median household income of $99,000, according to census data, attracts both young professionals and retirees looking for a walkable area that's a five-minute drive from downtown.

title: Streaming Services Draw New Subscribers With Old-Time Rock 'n' Roll
summary: Spotify, Amazon Music and Pandora all have recently installed new hires to promote older tunes. Joel Shaffer usually listens to current pop stars like Drake, Kygo and Migos during his 30-minute commute to work outside Boston. But when he recently stumbled onto Nine Inch Nails' 1989 song "Head Like a Hole," he was hooked.

title: Schools Pushed for Tech in Every Classroom. Now Parents Are Pushing Back.
summary: Resume Subscription. When Baltimore County, Md., public schools began going digital five years ago, textbooks disappeared from classrooms and paper and pencils were no longer encouraged. All students from kindergarten to 12th grade would eventually get a laptop, helping the district reach the "one-to-one" ratio of one for each child that has become coveted around the country. Teaching apps and digital courses took the place of flashcards and notebooks.

title: America's Stormy Affair With Apple AirPods: Love 'Em and Lose 'Em
summary: For some, anxiety over losing the popular wireless earphones clouds the liberating, wire-free experience. For months, Danny Shea suffered a low-level anxiety that finally lifted in June as he boarded a flight from Munich.

title: At Least 25 Dead in California Boat Fire
summary: At least 25 people confirmed dead as search continues for passengers aboard vessel off Santa Cruz Island. Dozens of people are dead after a fire destroyed a diving boat in Southern California, an event likely to rank among the nation's worst maritime tragedies in recent years.

title: Do You Remember? The Message in Earth, Wind & Fire's 'September'
summary: Resume Subscription. At the peak of their popularity in 1978, Earth, Wind & Fire needed a new single to include on its first album of greatest hits. "September" was written to help drive album sales.

title: Startups Snuggle Up to New York's Pampered Pets
summary: Entrepreneurs, investors in local pet-tech scene see growing opportunities to cater to animal lovers. At most business networking events, it still isn't proper to arrive accompanied by your dog. But at a recent Wall Street hotel mixer, designer Will Man and his mutt, Bentley, received a warm welcome. This was, after all, the NYC Pet Tech Meetup-a gathering of New Yorkers who are obsessed with pets and technology and, for better or worse, can't resist combining their passions.

title: A High-Tech Sports Bar on Wheels for Justin Moore
summary: Resume Subscription. Justin Moore, 35, a country music singer and songwriter from Poyen, Ark., on his Razorback tour bus, as told to A.J. Baime.

title: Beijing Asserts Power to Declare Emergency to Quell Hong Kong Unrest
summary: China's top office for Hong Kong affairs lays out specific measures for the city's leader to address protests. China's top office for Hong Kong affairs said it had legal power to unilaterally declare a state of emergency in the city if unrest continues unabated, while laying out specific measures for the city's leader to address protests.

title: Photos: The Bus Is Its Own Show
summary: Country star Justin Moore shows off his beloved Razorback tour bus from a stop in Louisville, Ky.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Bank of Canada Expected to Stand Pat This Week
summary: Economists predict bank officials will play down recent strength and highlight risks from trade tensions. OTTAWA-Market watchers predict the Bank of Canada will keep its benchmark interest rate unchanged Wednesday and hint it is ready to lower it to offset the fallout from escalating global trade tensions and slowing world economic growth.

title: Credit Unions Go On Bank Buying Spree
summary: Not-for-profit financial firms have acquired a record number of banks since last year. WASHINGTON-Credit unions are buying small banks in record numbers, a trend that is prompting pushback from the banking industry.

title: Why Boris Johnson Might Call an Election, and How He Could Get There
summary: U.K. could be headed for its third national election in four years. Here's what might lay ahead.. LONDON-Calling a general election in Britain used to be a simple matter. No longer.

title: Stocks to Watch: Alphabet, H&R Block, Conn's, and More
summary: Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Tuesday's session. Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Tuesday's session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours; premarket trading is specified separately.

title: Queer Eye's Antoni Porowski on How He Collects Sneakers
summary: The Netflix show's resident food and wine expert depends on a surprisingly non-food-related app: GOAT, for collecting rare sneakers.. Number of unread emails:

title: Trade-Secrets Case Seen as Warning to Silicon Valley
summary: U.S. prosecutors said to create 'chilling effect' by filing charges against driverless-car engineer. The federal indictment announced last week against a driverless-car engineer that accuses him of stealing trade secrets from Google's parent company before he jumped to a rival is being viewed as a warning to Silicon Valley that prosecutors may scrutinize defections to competitors that involve sensitive technology.

title: In Economics Profession, Hotel-Room Job Interviews Get Nixed
summary: Move by economics association is part of effort to address the field's 'reputation for hostility toward women and minorities'. Starting next year, aspiring professional economists will no longer have to sit through job interviews in a prospective employer's hotel room.

title: Thinning Liquidity Adds to Headaches for Traders
summary: As summer wanes, assets from stocks and bonds to currencies and derivatives are hard to trade. Investors already preoccupied with the trade battle between the U.S. and China and the prospect of a recession have another frustration: thinning liquidity.

title: The Hottest New Baseball Coaches Are Over 75
summary: Charlie Manuel, age 75, and Phil Regan, age 82, drew snickers when they were hired, but have proven that experience can be a valuable asset. Phil Regan and Charlie Manuel coached together with the Cleveland Indians in 1999. Regan was in charge of the pitchers. Manuel handled the hitters. At the time, the average age of a pitching or hitting coach in Major League Baseball was under 50-years-old. Regan and Manuel were 62 and 55, respectively, making them old for their jobs by any measurable standard.

title: Want to Save the Environment? Buy Oil Stocks
summary: A new economics paper argues that ethically-minded funds should diversify by investing unethically. Should green activists finance big oil corporations and anti-gun organizations lend money to arms manufacturers? As crazy as it sounds, financial theory provides a logically sound argument for why they ought to do just that.

title: Miami Office Developers Step on the Gas
summary: Office development in Miami has reached its highest level since 2009 thanks in part to tenants relocating from high-tax states. Like office-building developers in many U.S. cities, those in Miami have shown restraint during the financial recovery, adding new space at a modest pace.

title: Latest Oklahoma Export: Distressed Ukraine Loans
summary: Husband-and-wife team has carved a niche selling nonperforming loans, which have grown rapidly in several countries, including Ukraine. After years of war and economic malaise, Ukraine is struggling under a mountain of bad loans. Now the crisis is creating a business opportunity for an Oklahoma family company.

title: Hurricane Dorian Death Toll at Five in Bahamas as Storm Heads Toward U.S.
summary: Thousands of homes destroyed on islands; mandatory evacuation orders in Florida, Georgia, South Carolina. MELBOURNE, Fla.-Hurricane Dorian hovered over the northwestern Bahamas, killing at least five people, wiping out thousands of homes, forcing many into a makeshift shelter and leaving an entire island without power. The powerful storm was expected to near Florida late Tuesday.

title: A Flawed Cap-and-Trade Plan for Water Could Come to U.S.
summary: Resume Subscription. Australia's Darling River was once filled with fleets of paddle steamers carrying wool to ships bound for England. For nearly two centuries, it provided fresh water to farmers seeking to tame Australia's rugged interior.

title: Hong Kong Chief Carrie Lam Says She Never Tried to Resign
summary: 'The choice of not resigning is my own choice,' chief executive says. Embattled Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam said she has never tendered her resignation to Beijing and is committed to leading the city out of its monthslong political crisis.

title: No Turning Back the Clock in Chip Making
summary: Case against TSMC unlikely to shift competitive dynamics in semiconductor manufacturing. A new battle has emerged in the chip-making industry, though this one is unlikely to alter the rather harsh realities of that business.

title: Troubled Pot Industry Shows Its Pick-and-Shovel Trades
summary: Fertilizer company Scotts Miracle-Gro, real estate play IIP have outperformed marijuana stocks. Investment legend has it that the best money in the California gold rush was made selling picks and shovels. Fertilizer and real estate are equivalent bets on the volatile pot boom.

title: Chinese Steel Slowdown Slams Iron-Ore Prices
summary: After suffering its biggest one-month fall since 2011, the iron-ore market hinges on China's property sector. Iron-ore prices posted their biggest one-month fall in almost eight years as China's huge steel engine cools and global shipments of the commodity rise.

title: Hurricane Dorian Raises Question: Should There Be a Category 6?
summary: Most meteorologists say five categories is enough; 'you can't obliterate obliteration'. Hurricane Dorian is reviving a question that arises whenever the U.S. is threatened by the fiercest of hurricanes: Should there be a higher category designation, say a Category 6?

title: Van Eck, SolidX to Offer Limited Version of Bitcoin Exchange-Traded Fund
summary: Crypto enthusiasts have been trying with little success to get regulatory approval for bitcoin funds. Crypto enthusiasts have been trying without much success to get regulatory approval for funds to bring bitcoin to investors. Two firms plan to use a workaround.

title: Low Oil Prices Slam Saudi Economy
summary: Subdued crude sales are stunting Saudi growth, threatening the kingdom's foreign investment push and investor interest in an Aramco IPO. Subdued oil prices are punishing Saudi Arabia's economy, threatening the kingdom's foreign-investment push and curbing potential investor appetite for an Aramco IPO.

title: The End of Small-Town America, in the Heart of Seoul
summary: The oldest and most strategic U.S. base for deterring North Korea is moving out of the South's capital. SEOUL-The U.S. military's downtown Seoul home is an American oasis on its last legs. Rusted goal posts overlook a closed high school. The front lawns of identical ranch-style houses have turned brown. The narrow sidewalks, just wide enough for two people, have started to crack.

title: Yearslong Tax Dispute Could Cost Big Tech Companies Billions
summary: Facebook, Google are among firms caught in a battle between the IRS and an Intel unit over rules issued in 2003. A long-running tax dispute is racking up a potentially hefty price tag of nearly $2 billion and counting for dozens of big U.S. companies, including Facebook Inc. and Alphabet Inc.

title: Lego's Bid to Beat the Pack Results in Sharp Drop in Profit
summary: Toy maker is competing for children's attention with video games, YouTube and other digital distractions. Lego A/S reported a sharp drop in half-year profit as it plowed money into new stores and rolling out products and digital initiatives in a bid to stay ahead of fast-changing consumer behavior.

title: U.S. Tells Afghanistan It Will Withdraw Some Troops Within 135 Days of Pact
summary: Chief U.S. diplomat overseeing talks with the Taliban shared details of the proposal with the Afghan government. KABUL-With an accord on the withdrawal of U.S. troops from Afghanistan in sight, the chief U.S. diplomat overseeing talks with the Taliban shared details of the proposed accord with a crucial, but largely sidelined, stakeholder: the Afghan government.

title: Why You Need to Add Tahini Cookies to Your Repertoire
summary: You only need a few ingredients to make this recipe. One of them provides infinite complexity. NUTTY, LUSCIOUS tahini features in many of the dishes at Nur, in Manhattan. Chef Meir Adoni drizzles the sesame paste on his smoked eggplant carpaccio and his branzino, his vegetable couscous and his pan-roasted octopus. Come dessert, it plays a starring role in the tahini cookies, imparting an unforgettable toasty aroma. If a cookie can be said to have a long finish, this one does.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: P&G Takes Tide to the Cleaners
summary: With big brands under attack, Tide dry-cleaning business is growing, with more locations, campus delivery and wash-and-fold service. SUMMIT, N.J.-Procter & Gamble Co. started a dry-cleaning chain a decade ago to market detergent and learn more about how consumers like their laundry. That experiment has evolved into the sector's second-largest U.S. competitor as mom-and-pop rivals struggle.

title: Impasse on Infrastructure Funding Stirs Concern
summary: Amid stalemate in Washington, experts say neglecting roads and bridges poses safety risk. As Congress returns for the fall, President Trump and congressional Democrats remain stalemated over moving forward on a large infrastructure package that advocates and engineers say is urgently needed.

title: Trade Disputes Curb Global Factory Activity as Confidence Wanes
summary: The manufacturing activity slowdown has been exacerbated by the escalating trade war between the U.S. and China. The fallout from an escalating trade war between the U.S. and China is rippling through the global economy, crimping growth in Asian industrial giants such as Japan and South Korea and hitting factories as far away from the front line as Germany.
